column4: hey all.  I can't get my fresh Ubuntu 6.10 install to connect to the internet. onboard ethernet on a P5B Deluxe.  any ideas?
sudo ifup?
i haven't tried that. I will try that. have you got any other ideas. this is a dual boot system. I'm on another OS right now
ok, go back to the other system, and do an sudo ifconfig -a
see if your network card is being detected by ubuntu
k, i'm actually pretty certain it's being detected. i see it in the device manager
ok, do sudo ifup ** where ** is the name of the network interface - something like eth0, eth1, etc
alright, thanks a lot
np
I got this message- ifup: interface eth0 already configured
so were you able to connect? I assume that eth0 corresponds to your network card.
eth0 is my network card.  but on the ASUS P5B Deluxe, there are TWO onboard ethernet jacks, only one is showing up. I was not able to connect
2 jacks? for 2 seperate cards?
if you have 2 cards, then does eth0 correspond to the right one?
good point.  I hadn't thought about switching the cable.
but I don't understand why only one of them show up.
not sure I comprehend. you're telling me that sudo ifconfig -a doesn't show the proper network card?
I assume you did a standard ubuntu install via an install cd. during the installation, did the installer detect both cards?
i forgot to try that. the only thing i tried was sudo ifup **
good god.
the install said nothing of network cards
the install should've attempted to detect network interfaces. all of them. wireless/wired/modem/whatever.
if you didn't do sudo ifconfig -a , then how do you know what to put for sudo ifup **???
i looked it up in device manager, actually
and i remember from earlier ubuntu installations, that the install would look for network interfaces, but i did not notice it this time.
oh crap - gotta chk nbc 4
again, do a sudo ifconfig -a. that's all I have to say.
okay, thanks for your help
sudo ifconfig -a produced about 3 paragraphs of results.
sudo ifconfig -a > ~/netdat
and read at your own pace
you have to open ~/netdat
k
maddish: thanks again
np. that's a lot of network interfaces, btw.
